---
title: "Machine Learning Reading List"
---

<br>

## Articles

| Citation | Link | Why I Like It |
|----------|------|---------------|
| Breiman L. Statistical Modeling: The Two Cultures. *Statistical Science*. 2001. | [Link](https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.ss/1009213726) | Seminal work on the distinction between classical statistical modeling and algorithmic modeling approaches. |
| Bi Q, et al. What is Machine Learning?: A Primer for Epidemiologists. *American Journal of Epidemiology*. 2019. | [Link](https://academic.oup.com/aje/article/188/12/2222/5486372) | Excellent introduction to machine learning concepts and issues specifically for epidemiologists. |
| Naimi AI, Balzer L. Stacked Generalization: An Introduction to Super Learning. *European Journal of Epidemiology*. 2018. | [Link](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10654-018-0390-z) | Demonstrates the fundamentals behind the super learner algorithm. |
| Kennedy CJ. Guide to Super Learner. 2017. | [Link](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/SuperLearner/vignettes/Guide-to-SuperLearner.html) | Detailed practical resource on using the super learner in real data settings. |
| Chouldechova A. Fair prediction with disparate impact: a study of bias in recidivism prediction instruments. 2016. | [Link](https://arxiv.org/abs/1610.07524) | Important example of fundamental constraints on using algorithms to predict outcomes fairly. |
| Mullainathan S, Spiess J. Machine learning: an applied econometric approach. *Journal of Economic Perspectives*. 2017;31(2):87-106. | [Link](https://www.aeaweb.org/articles?id=10.1257/jep.31.2.87) | Excellent introduction to machine learning with emphasis on econometrics, very useful for epidemiologists. |
| Caruana R, et al. Intelligible Models for HealthCare: Predicting Pneumonia Risk and Hospital 30-day Readmission. *KDD*. 2015. | [Link](https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/2783258.2788613) | Important example of how ML algorithms can yield misleading predictions when deeper data-modeling complexities aren't considered. |

<br>

## Books

### Technical Skills

| Citation | Link | Why I Like It |
|----------|------|---------------|
| Burkov A. The Hundred Page Machine Learning Book. 2019. | [Link](http://themlbook.com/) | Concise, accessible introduction to core ML concepts. |
| Burkov A. Machine Learning Engineering. 2021. | [Link](http://www.mlebook.com/) | Practical guide to productionizing ML systems. |
| Kuhn M, Johnson K. Applied Predictive Modeling. 2016. | [Link](https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-1-4614-6849-3) | Comprehensive practical guide to predictive modeling techniques. |

<br>

### Conceptual/Theoretical Understanding & Social Issues

| Citation | Link | Why I Like It |
|----------|------|---------------|
| Mitchell M. Artificial Intelligence: A Guide for Thinking Humans. 2019. | [Link](https://melaniemitchell.me/aibook/) | Essential reading on AI from a thoughtful, critical perspective. |
| Broussard M. Artificial Unintelligence: How Computers Misunderstand the World. 2019. | [Link](https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262537018/artificial-unintelligence/) | Important critique of how algorithms fail to understand context and nuance. |

<br>

### Advanced Texts

| Citation | Link | Why I Like It |
|----------|------|---------------|
| Wasserman L. All of Nonparametric Statistics. 2006. | [Link](https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/0-387-30623-4) | Comprehensive theoretical foundation for nonparametric methods. |
| Shalev-Shwartz S, Ben-David S. Understanding Machine Learning: From Theory to Algorithms. 2014. | [Link](https://www.cs.huji.ac.il/~shais/UnderstandingMachineLearning/) | Rigorous theoretical treatment of ML fundamentals. |
| Efron B, Hastie T. Computer Age Statistical Inference: Algorithms, Evidence, and Data Science. 2017. | [Link](https://web.stanford.edu/~hastie/CASI/) | Modern perspective connecting classical and contemporary statistical methods. |
| Hastie T, Tibshirani R, Friedman J. Elements of Statistical Learning. 2009. | [Link](https://hastie.su.domains/ElemStatLearn/) | Classic comprehensive reference on statistical learning methods. |
| James G, Witten D, Hastie T, Tibshirani R. Introduction to Statistical Learning. 2017. | [Link](https://www.statlearning.com/) | Accessible introduction to statistical learning with R examples. |
